hints: The rate of change of velocity over time.
A vector quantity measured in meters per second squared.
Causes an object's speed or direction to change.
Speed in a given direction.
A vector quantity.
Displacement divided by time.
The product of an object's mass and its velocity.
A measure of an object's motion.
Often conserved in collisions.
A push or a pull on an object.
Causes a change in motion.
Measured in Newtons.
The force that attracts objects with mass towards each other.
Keeps planets in orbit around the sun.
Responsible for objects falling to the ground.
A force that opposes motion between surfaces in contact.
Can generate heat.
Can be reduced by lubrication.
The capacity to do work.
Comes in many forms, such as kinetic and potential.
Measured in Joules.
The rate at which work is done.
Energy transferred per unit of time.
Measured in Watts.
The transfer of energy by a force moving an object.
Force multiplied by displacement.
Measured in Joules.
A measure of the amount of matter in an object.
Often confused with weight.
Causes a gravitational field.
The force of gravity on an object.
Varies depending on location in the universe.
The product of an object's mass and acceleration due to gravity.
Force applied per unit area.
The air in a tire exerts this on the rubber.
Measured in Pascals.
Mass per unit volume.
Determines if an object will sink or float.
A measure of how tightly matter is packed together.
A disturbance that transfers energy through a medium.
Can be transverse or longitudinal.
Light and sound are examples.
The number of cycles of a wave that pass a point in a given amount of time.
Measured in Hertz.
Determines the pitch of a sound.
The distance between two consecutive peaks or troughs of a wave.
Represented by the Greek letter lambda.
Shorter for high-frequency light.
The maximum displacement or distance moved by a point on a vibrating body or wave.
Determines the loudness of a sound.
The height of a wave.
A longitudinal wave that travels through a medium.
Requires a medium like air or water to propagate.
Its speed is slower than the speed of light.
A form of electromagnetic radiation.
Travels as a transverse wave.
The fastest speed in the universe.
The bending of light as it passes from one medium to another.
Causes a straw in a glass of water to look bent.
The principle behind lenses and eyeglasses.
The bouncing back of a wave from a surface.
Causes you to see your image in a mirror.
The angle of incidence equals the angle of this.
The flow of electric charge.
Powers most modern devices.
Can be generated from various sources like dams and solar panels.
The electric potential difference between two points.
Often referred to as electric pressure.
Measured in Volts.
The rate of flow of electric charge.
Measured in Amperes.
Can be alternating or direct.
A measure of opposition to the flow of electric current.
Causes a conductor to heat up.
Measured in Ohms.
A complete path for an electric current.
Can be in series or parallel.
Contains components like resistors and capacitors.
A force that attracts or repels objects.
Caused by moving electric charges.
Creates a field with North and South poles.
Relating to the smallest discrete unit of a physical property.
The basis of modern physics.
The physics of the very small.
A theory developed by Albert Einstein.
Explains the relationship between space, time, mass, and energy.
Includes concepts like time dilation and length contraction.
The study of heat and its relationship to energy and work.
Includes four laws.
The first law states energy cannot be created or destroyed.
A measure of disorder or randomness in a system.
The second law of thermodynamics states it always increases in an isolated system.
Often used to describe the arrow of time.
A subatomic particle with a positive charge.
Found in the nucleus of an atom.
Number of these determines an element's identity.
A subatomic particle with no charge.
Found in the nucleus of an atom.
Its number can vary, creating isotopes.
A negatively charged subatomic particle.
Orbits the nucleus of an atom.
Its flow is what we call electric current.
The fundamental particle of light.
Has no mass.
A quantum of the electromagnetic field.
A fundamental particle of matter.
Combines to form protons and neutrons.
Comes in six 'flavors': up, down, strange, charm, top, and bottom.
A type of subatomic particle that carries forces.
The Higgs particle is an example.
Follows Bose-Einstein statistics.
A type of subatomic particle that makes up matter.
Electrons, protons, and neutrons are examples.
Obeys the Pauli Exclusion Principle.
A state where a material has zero electrical resistance.
Requires extremely low temperatures.
Used in MRI machines and powerful magnets.
The splitting of a heavy atomic nucleus.
Releases a large amount of energy.
Used in nuclear power plants and atomic bombs.
The combining of two light atomic nuclei.
Powers the sun and other stars.
A potential source of clean energy on Earth.
An invisible substance that makes up most of the mass in the universe.
Its existence is inferred from gravitational effects.
Does not emit, absorb, or reflect light.
A region of spacetime with gravity so strong nothing can escape.
Formed from the collapse of a massive star.
Has an event horizon.
Ripples in the fabric of spacetime.
Predicted by Einstein's theory of general relativity.
First directly detected by the LIGO experiment in 2015.
The change in frequency of a wave in relation to an observer.
Explains why the pitch of an ambulance siren changes as it passes.
Causes a redshift for distant galaxies.
The time it takes for half of a radioactive substance to decay.
Used in radiocarbon dating.
A key concept in nuclear physics.
German physicist who is the founder of quantum theory.
His constant relates energy to the frequency of light.
He received the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1918.
German theoretical physicist who was one of the key pioneers of quantum mechanics.
Known for his uncertainty principle.
Received the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1932.
English physicist and mathematician.
Developed the three laws of motion.
Credited with developing the law of universal gravitation.
German-born theoretical physicist.
Developed the theory of relativity.
Famous for the equation E=mc².
Italian astronomer, physicist, and engineer.
Pioneer of experimental physics.
Supported the heliocentric model of the solar system.
English scientist who contributed to the study of electromagnetism.
Invented the electric motor.
His law describes electromagnetic induction.
Ancient Greek mathematician, physicist, and engineer.
Known for his principle concerning buoyancy.
He reportedly shouted 'Eureka!'.
German astronomer.
His three laws describe the motion of planets around the Sun.
A key figure in the scientific revolution.
American astronomer.
He provided evidence for the expansion of the universe.
The famous space telescope is named after him.
Austrian physicist who contributed to quantum theory.
Famous for his thought experiment involving a cat.
Developed the wave equation for quantum mechanics.
The scientific study of the origin and evolution of the universe.
Deals with the Big Bang theory.
Studies the largest-scale structures of the universe.
The branch of physics that studies the physical properties of celestial objects.
Applies the laws of physics to stars, galaxies, and planets.
The science of space.
An instrument used to measure temperature.
Invented by Galileo.
Can use mercury or alcohol.
An instrument used to measure atmospheric pressure.
Can predict weather changes.
Invented by Evangelista Torricelli.
Energy of motion.
Calculated as one-half the mass times velocity squared.
A moving car has a lot of this.
Stored energy.
Energy an object has due to its position or state.
A ball at the top of a hill has a lot of this.
The strong force that binds protons and neutrons together.
Extremely powerful but has a very short range.
Overcomes the electromagnetic repulsion between protons.
A theoretical framework in which point-like particles are replaced by one-dimensional objects.
Proposes that fundamental particles are tiny vibrating strings.
Attempts to unify all fundamental forces.
A measure of spatial extent.
Length, width, and height are examples.
Some theories suggest there are more than three.
The transfer of heat through direct contact.
The heat from a hot pan moves through the handle.
Occurs primarily in solids.
The transfer of heat through the movement of fluids.
Responsible for weather patterns and ocean currents.
Boiling water is a good example.
The transfer of energy by electromagnetic waves or particles.
The heat you feel from the sun.
Can be harmful in high doses.
A powerful and luminous stellar explosion.
Can briefly outshine an entire galaxy.
Leaves behind a neutron star or a black hole.
A highly magnetized rotating neutron star.
Emits beams of electromagnetic radiation.
Appears to 'pulse' at regular intervals.
An extremely luminous and distant active galactic nucleus.
Often the most powerful and energetic objects in the universe.
Shines brighter than hundreds of galaxies.
A space devoid of matter.
Used in thermos bottles for insulation.
Space is a near-perfect example of this.
The basic unit of an element.
Consists of a nucleus and electrons.
Means 'uncuttable' in Greek.
Subatomic particle with a positive charge.
Number of these defines an element.
Found in the nucleus.
Subatomic particle with no charge.
Found in the nucleus.
Discovered by James Chadwick.
Subatomic particle with a negative charge.
Orbits the nucleus.
Its flow is electric current.
The fourth state of matter.
An ionized gas.
Found in stars and lightning.
A device that emits a concentrated beam of coherent light.
An acronym for 'Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation'.
Used in surgery, scanners, and pointers.
A technique that allows an image to be recorded in three dimensions.
Uses laser light to create a photographic plate.
The result is a a three-dimensional image.
A type of telescope that uses mirrors.
Developed by Isaac Newton.
Its mirrors focus light to form an image.
A type of telescope that uses lenses.
Suffers from chromatic aberration.
Galileo used a telescope of this type.
The branch of mechanics that deals with forces and their effect on motion.
Studies why objects move the way they do.
Involves Newton's laws of motion.
The study of objects at rest or in equilibrium.
Deals with forces without motion.
A bridge is an example of this kind of system.
The study of how fluids move and interact.
Includes both liquids and gases.
Important for designing airplanes and boats.
The study of the motion of liquids.
A sub-field of fluid dynamics.
Pertains to water flow and waves.
The study of how gases move and interact.
A sub-field of fluid dynamics.
Crucial for aircraft and car design.
The branch of physics that deals with sound.
Studies how sound is produced, transmitted, and received.
Architects consider this when designing concert halls.
The branch of physics that deals with light.
Studies the behavior and properties of light.
Involves mirrors, lenses, and prisms.
The measurement of heat changes.
Used to determine the specific heat of substances.
A key technique in thermodynamics.
The amount of heat required to raise the temperature of a substance.
Water has a very high value of this.
Measured in joules per kilogram per Kelvin.
An electronic component that stores electrical energy.
Consists of two conductive plates separated by a dielectric.
Used in timing circuits and power supplies.
An electronic component that limits or regulates the flow of current.
Its value is measured in Ohms.
Often has colored bands on it to indicate its value.
An electronic component that stores energy in a magnetic field.
Made of a coil of wire.
Opposes changes in current.
An electronic component that allows current to flow in only one direction.
Used in rectifiers to convert AC to DC.
A light-emitting one is a common electronic component.
An electronic component that can amplify or switch electronic signals.
The fundamental building block of modern electronics.
Invented at Bell Labs.
A material with electrical conductivity between a conductor and an insulator.
Silicon and Germanium are common examples.
The basis for all modern computer chips.
A sensor used to measure temperature.
Consists of two different metals joined together.
Produces a voltage that changes with temperature.
The emission of electrons from a metal when light shines on it.
Einstein explained this phenomenon in 1905.
The basis for solar cells and light meters.
A stream of electrons observed in a vacuum tube.
J.J. Thomson used these to discover the electron.
The basis of old television screens.
A machine that speeds up subatomic particles.
Used to study the fundamental structure of matter.
The Large Hadron Collider is an example.
A type of particle accelerator.
Uses a magnetic field to make particles move in a spiral path.
Invented by Ernest Lawrence.
A type of particle accelerator that uses a ring to keep particles moving.
The magnetic field is synchronized with the particle's energy.
The Large Hadron Collider is one of these.
The area around a magnet where a magnetic force can be felt.
Represented by field lines.
Caused by moving electric charges.
The area around an electric charge where an electric force can be felt.
Points in the direction a positive charge would move.
Measured in Newtons per Coulomb.
Radiation from the early universe.
Often abbreviated as CMB.
Provides strong evidence for the Big Bang theory.
The rate at which the universe is expanding.
Relates the velocity of galaxies to their distance.
A key parameter in cosmology.
The increase in wavelength of light from distant galaxies.
Indicates that objects are moving away from us.
An example of the Doppler effect in light.
The leading theory for the origin of the universe.
A moment of rapid expansion from a single point.
Occurred approximately 13.8 billion years ago.
A point of infinite density and zero volume.
The center of a black hole.
The state of the universe before the Big Bang.
The boundary of a black hole.
The point of no return.
Anything that crosses this cannot escape, not even light.
A hypothetical shortcut through spacetime.
Could potentially connect two different points in space and time.
A popular concept in science fiction.
A four-dimensional continuum of three spatial dimensions and one time dimension.
Einstein's theory of relativity describes it.
Mass and energy can warp and curve it.
The slowing of time for an object in motion or in a strong gravitational field.
A key prediction of Einstein's theory of relativity.
Means clocks tick slower for objects moving at high speeds.
A fundamental particle responsible for giving other particles mass.
Sometimes called the 'God particle'.
Discovered at the Large Hadron Collider.
A fundamental particle that mediates the strong nuclear force.
Binds quarks together to form protons and neutrons.
The name comes from its 'sticky' nature.
Matter composed of antiparticles.
When it meets regular matter, they annihilate each other.
Has opposite charge and spin to normal matter.
A fundamental particle with almost no mass and no charge.
Can pass through ordinary matter with almost no interaction.
Billions of them pass through you every second.
A phenomenon where a particle can pass through a potential barrier.
Not possible in classical physics.
Essential for nuclear fusion in the sun.
A principle of quantum mechanics.
A quantum system can exist in multiple states at once.
Schrödinger's cat thought experiment illustrates this.
A phenomenon where two particles are linked, no matter the distance.
Measuring a property of one particle instantly affects the other.
Einstein called it 'spooky action at a distance'.
A hypothetical elementary particle that mediates the force of gravity.
Has not yet been discovered.
Predicted by some theories of quantum gravity.
A logarithmic unit used to measure sound intensity.
Often abbreviated as dB.
A whisper is around 30 of these.
The base unit of length in the International System of Units.
Originally defined as one ten-millionth of the distance from the North Pole to the Equator.
About 39.37 inches.
The base unit of mass in the International System of Units.
Originally defined by a metal cylinder in France.
Approximately 2.2 pounds.
The base unit of time in the International System of Units.
Originally defined by the rotation of the Earth.
Now defined by the radiation of a Cesium-133 atom.
The base unit of electric current in the International System of Units.
Often abbreviated as A.
Named after a French physicist.
The base unit of temperature in the International System of Units.
Zero on this scale is absolute zero.
Named after a British physicist.
The SI unit of energy and work.
The energy required to exert one Newton of force over one meter.
Named after James Prescott Joule.
The SI unit of power.
A measure of energy per unit time.
Named after James Watt.
The SI unit of electric potential difference.
Often referred to as electric 'pressure'.
Named after Alessandro Volta.
The SI unit of electrical resistance.
Named after Georg Simon Ohm.
Resistance is measured in these.
The SI unit of frequency.
One of these is one cycle per second.
Named after Heinrich Hertz.
The SI unit of pressure.
Named after Blaise Pascal.
One of these is one Newton per square meter.
The SI unit of electric charge.
Named after Charles-Augustin de Coulomb.
Equal to the charge of approximately $6.24 	imes 10^{18}$ electrons.
The SI unit of magnetic field strength.
Named after Nikola Tesla.
A very strong magnetic field.
A fundamental law of physics.
States that energy cannot be created or destroyed.
It can only be converted from one form to another.
A fundamental law of physics.
States that the total momentum of a system remains constant.
Explains what happens in a game of billiards.
The law of inertia.
An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion.
Part of Isaac Newton's three laws of motion.
Relates force, mass, and acceleration.
Expressed as the equation F=ma.
Part of Isaac Newton's three laws of motion.
The law of action and reaction.
For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
Part of Isaac Newton's three laws of motion.
Relates voltage, current, and resistance in a circuit.
Expressed as the equation V=IR.
Named after a German physicist.
The tendency of matter to change in volume in response to a change in temperature.
Why bridges have expansion joints.
Why a thermometer works.
States that two or more waves can combine to create a new wave.
The new wave is the sum of the individual waves.
Explains constructive and destructive interference.
One thousand kilograms per cubic meter.
A reference point for specific gravity.
An object with a higher value of this will sink.
The upward force exerted by a fluid that opposes the weight of an immersed object.
Makes a boat float.
Described by Archimedes' Principle.
A measure of a fluid's resistance to flow.
Honey has a high value of this, while water has a low one.
Often described as the 'thickness' of a fluid.
The resistance of an object to a change in its state of motion.
The basis of Newton's First Law.
A stationary object has this.
A measure of an object's resistance to angular acceleration.
A key concept in rotational motion.
The rotational analogue of mass.
A twisting force that causes rotation.
The force applied to a wrench to turn a bolt.
The rotational analogue of force.
A force that keeps an object moving in a circle.
Directed toward the center of the circular path.
The tension in a string when you swing a ball around.
A fictitious force that appears to push an object away from the center of a circular path.
What you feel when a car turns sharply.
A result of inertia, not a real force.
The change in momentum of an object.
The product of force and the time interval over which it is applied.
A short, sharp hit to a baseball.
A weight suspended from a pivot that can swing freely.
Its period depends on its length, not its mass.
Used in clocks and to measure gravity.
A type of oscillatory motion where the restoring force is directly proportional to the displacement.
The motion of a pendulum or a mass on a spring.
Can be described by a sine or cosine function.
A phenomenon where an object is made to vibrate at its natural frequency.
Can cause a wine glass to break when a singer hits a high note.
Important for radio receivers.
The point at which a moving object's speed equals the speed of sound.
Breaking it creates a sonic boom.
Often referred to as Mach 1.
Moving at a speed less than the speed of sound.
Most airplanes fly at this speed.
Below Mach 1.
Moving at a speed greater than the speed of sound.
A jet fighter can do this.
Above Mach 1.
A wave in which particles of the medium vibrate at right angles to the direction of wave travel.
Light is an example of this.
Can be polarized.
A wave in which particles of the medium vibrate parallel to the direction of wave travel.
Sound is an example of this.
Has compressions and rarefactions.
The range of all types of electromagnetic radiation.
Includes radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible light, ultraviolet, X-rays, and gamma rays.
Arranged by wavelength and frequency.
A type of electromagnetic radiation.
Used for cooking food and in radar.
Has a longer wavelength than visible light.
A type of electromagnetic radiation.
Felt as heat from a fire.
Used in night vision technology and remote controls.
A type of electromagnetic radiation.
Can cause sunburns.
Blocked by the ozone layer.
A type of electromagnetic radiation.
Used in medicine to see bones.
Discovered by Wilhelm Rontgen.
The highest energy electromagnetic radiation.
Produced by radioactive decay.
Used in cancer treatment and sterilization.
Describes the electrostatic force between charged particles.
Similar to Newton's law of gravitation.
States that force is proportional to the product of charges and inversely proportional to the square of the distance.
Relates voltage, current, and resistance.
The formula is $V = IR$.
Named after a German physicist.
Describes how a changing magnetic field creates an electric current.
The basis for electric generators and transformers.
Crucial for understanding how electricity is generated.
States that an induced current creates a magnetic field that opposes the change that created it.
A consequence of the conservation of energy.
Explains why it's harder to push a magnet into a coil of wire quickly.
A fundamental physical constant in quantum mechanics.
Relates the energy of a photon to its frequency.
Represented by the symbol $h$.
A fundamental principle of quantum mechanics.
States that we cannot simultaneously know the exact position and momentum of a particle.
Formulated by Werner Heisenberg.
States that no two fermions can occupy the same quantum state simultaneously.
Explains the structure of the periodic table.
Named after Wolfgang Pauli.
The process that produced the first light elements in the early universe.
Occurred in the first few minutes after the Big Bang.
Responsible for the observed abundance of hydrogen and helium.
The process of becoming wider, larger, or more open.
In physics, it refers to the slowing of time.
A key effect of relativity.
The relationship between mass and energy.
Expressed by Einstein's equation E=mc².
Implies that mass can be converted into energy and vice versa.
A theoretical framework that combines quantum mechanics and special relativity.
Describes particles as excitations of underlying fields.
The Standard Model of particle physics is built on this.
The theory that describes the fundamental particles and forces of nature.
Includes quarks, leptons, and bosons.
Does not include gravity.
A composite particle made of quarks.
Protons and neutrons are examples.
Interacts via the strong nuclear force.
A fundamental particle that is not affected by the strong nuclear force.
Electrons and neutrinos are examples.
Comes in three 'flavors'.
High-energy particles that originate from outer space.
Can hit the Earth's atmosphere and produce showers of secondary particles.
Discovered by Victor Hess.
A region of space where stars are born.
Also known as a nebula.
Consists of dense clouds of gas and dust.
The dense core of a low-mass star after it has exhausted its fuel.
Very small and hot.
Eventually cools down to become a black dwarf.
A superdense stellar remnant formed from the collapse of a massive star.
Composed almost entirely of neutrons.
A spoonful of this would weigh billions of tons.
A system of two stars orbiting a common center of mass.
They can be a source of gravitational waves.
Most stars in the galaxy are part of one of these.
Approaches infinity at the center.
A point of infinite density.
A key characteristic of a singularity.
The process that powers stars.
Combines light atomic nuclei to form heavier ones.
Releases a tremendous amount of energy.
The electrostatic repulsion that prevents two atomic nuclei from fusing.
Must be overcome for nuclear fusion to occur.
Overcome by high temperatures and pressures in stars.
The study of the fourth state of matter.
Deals with ionized gases.
Important for understanding stars and fusion reactors.
A type of computation that uses quantum-mechanical phenomena.
Can solve certain problems much faster than classical computers.
Uses qubits instead of bits.
The transfer of a quantum state from one location to another.
Does not involve moving matter or energy.
Depends on quantum entanglement.
The loss of quantum coherence.
Explains why quantum effects are not observed in everyday life.
Caused by interaction with the environment.
The idea that the act of observing a system changes it.
A key concept in the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics.
Illustrated by the double-slit experiment.
A theory of the very early universe.
Proposes an extremely rapid expansion of space.
Explains the large-scale uniformity of the universe.
The energy that exists in space, even in the absence of matter.
A key concept in the expansion of the universe.
A type of dark energy.
A physical force arising from a quantized field.
Two uncharged conductive plates in a vacuum will attract each other.
A consequence of quantum field theory.
The bending of light by a massive object.
Predicted by Einstein's theory of general relativity.
Can cause distant objects to appear distorted or multiplied.
Describes the relationship between a galaxy's distance and its recession speed.
States that distant galaxies are moving away from us faster than close ones.
Provides evidence for the expansion of the universe.
A small localized object to which can be ascribed several physical properties.
Can be a subatomic particle like an electron or a larger object.
A fundamental building block of matter.
A composite subatomic particle made of three quarks.
Protons and neutrons are the most common examples.
A type of hadron.
A composite subatomic particle made of a quark and an antiquark.
Pions and kaons are examples.
A type of hadron.
A composite particle made of quarks.
Baryons and mesons are examples.
Interacts via the strong force.
Relic neutrinos from the Big Bang.
Similar to the CMB, but for a different particle.
Has not yet been directly detected.
A non-random motion of galaxy clusters.
Suggests a pull from beyond the visible universe.
Disputed by some scientists.
A state of matter where a fluid has zero viscosity.
Can flow up the sides of a container.
Helium-4 exhibits this at very low temperatures.
A semiconductor nanocrystal with quantum mechanical properties.
Emits light of a specific color depending on its size.
Used in modern television screens.
A nickname for neutrinos.
Because they rarely interact with matter.
They pass through us almost unnoticed.
The electrostatic force of attraction or repulsion between charges.
Described by Coulomb's Law.
Stronger than gravity at the atomic level.
All of space and time and their contents.
Includes planets, stars, galaxies, and all forms of matter and energy.
Its origin is described by the Big Bang theory.
The electrical potential difference produced by an energy source.
Also known as voltage.
Often abbreviated as EMF.
A type of particle accelerator that moves particles in a straight line.
The particles are accelerated by a series of alternating electric fields.
Used in medicine for radiation therapy.
A device used to initiate and control a sustained nuclear chain reaction.
Generates heat to produce electricity.
The core contains fuel rods and control rods.
A device that uses nuclear fusion to generate power.
Still in the experimental stage.
The Sun is a natural example of one.
A substance in a nuclear reactor that slows down neutrons.
This is done to increase the likelihood of fission.
Graphite and heavy water are examples.
Rods made of neutron-absorbing material.
Used to regulate the rate of fission in a nuclear reactor.
Can be inserted or removed to speed up or slow down the reaction.
The process by which an unstable atomic nucleus loses energy by emitting radiation.
Can be alpha, beta, or gamma decay.
Its rate is measured in half-life.
A method for determining the age of organic matter.
Based on the half-life of Carbon-14.
Used by archaeologists to date artifacts.
The radioactive material created by a nuclear explosion.
Can contaminate a wide area.
Causes long-term health risks.
A secret research and development project during World War II.
Led to the creation of the first nuclear weapons.
Its main research facility was in Los Alamos.
The site of a major nuclear disaster in 1986.
Located in Ukraine.
The disaster resulted in a large exclusion zone.
A fundamental physical constant in the law of universal gravitation.
Represented by the symbol G.
Its value is approximately 6.674 × 10⁻¹¹ N·m²/kg².
A fundamental physical constant relating kinetic energy to temperature.
Used in statistical mechanics.
Represented by the symbol $k_B$.
A set of laws that describe the relationship between pressure, volume, and temperature of a gas.
Includes Boyle's Law, Charles's Law, and Gay-Lussac's Law.
Describes the behavior of an ideal gas.
States that for a fixed amount of gas at constant temperature, pressure and volume are inversely proportional.
As you squeeze a balloon, the pressure inside increases.
Named after Robert Boyle.
States that for a fixed amount of gas at constant pressure, volume is directly proportional to temperature.
A balloon shrinks when it gets cold.
Named after Jacques Charles.
States that for a fixed amount of gas at constant volume, pressure is directly proportional to temperature.
A pressure cooker is a good example.
Named after Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac.
The emission of electrons from a metal when light shines on it.
Explained by Albert Einstein.
The basis for solar panels and photocells.
The release of electrons from a heated material.
Used in vacuum tubes and old cathode ray tubes.
A source of free electrons.
The idea that a physical quantity can only take on discrete values.
Energy levels in an atom are an example.
A central concept in quantum mechanics.
A theoretical framework that aims to unify the four fundamental forces of nature.
Einstein worked on this for many years.
String theory is a modern example.
A hypothetical principle that relates bosons and fermions.
Predicts that every particle has a 'superpartner'.
Has not yet been confirmed by experiment.
Hypothetical one-dimensional topological defects in spacetime.
Formed during a phase transition in the early universe.
Have not been observed.
The hypothesis that our universe is just one of many.
A concept from some theories of cosmology and quantum mechanics.
Often used in science fiction.
The study of complex, dynamic systems that are sensitive to initial conditions.
The butterfly effect is an example.
Applies to weather systems and population growth.
The physics of the Earth and its environment.
Studies earthquakes, volcanoes, and the Earth's magnetic field.
Uses principles from seismology and meteorology.
The application of physics principles to biological systems.
Studies how molecules, cells, and organs work.
Includes the study of photosynthesis and nerve impulses.
The average distance from the Earth to the Sun.
Used for measuring distances within our solar system.
Approximately 150 million kilometers.
The distance light travels in one year.
A unit of distance, not time.
Equal to about $9.46 	imes 10^{15}$ meters.
A unit of distance used in astronomy.
Derived using parallax and trigonometry.
Approximately 3.26 light years.
The radius of a sphere such that if all the mass of an object were compressed within it, the escape velocity from the surface would equal the speed of light.
Defines the event horizon of a non-rotating black hole.
Named after Karl Schwarzschild.
The creation of voltage and electric current in a material upon exposure to light.
The principle behind solar cells.
A specific type of photoelectric effect.
The transition of an electron from one energy level to another within an atom.
A discrete jump, not a continuous change.
Often used colloquially to mean a big step forward.
The study of the interaction between matter and electromagnetic radiation.
Used to identify the chemical composition of stars.
Analyzes the spectrum of light.
A type of radar that uses the Doppler effect to measure the speed of objects.
Used to track tornadoes and hurricanes.
Also used by police to measure vehicle speed.
Relating to nuclear reactions that occur at very high temperatures.
The type of fusion that occurs in stars.
A term used for hydrogen bombs.
The use of sound waves to suspend matter in the air.
A non-contact method of manipulating objects.
Works by using pressure from standing sound waves.
The branch of physics that deals with very low temperatures.
Involves the study of how materials behave near absolute zero.
Used for freezing and storing biological samples.
The study of the magnetic properties and behavior of electrically conducting fluids.
Often abbreviated as MHD.
Applies to stars, stellar winds, and fusion research.
The direct conversion of temperature differences to electric voltage and vice versa.
Used in space probes like Voyager 1 and 2.
Consists of three related phenomena: Seebeck, Peltier, and Thomson effects.
The theory of the strong nuclear force.
Describes the interactions between quarks and gluons.
Often abbreviated as QCD.
A device used to observe high-energy particles from space.
Can be a cloud chamber or a Geiger counter.
Used to study the composition of cosmic rays.
A device used to detect, track, and identify elementary particles.
Examples include cloud chambers and bubble chambers.
Essential for research at particle accelerators.
A theoretical framework that seeks to unify quantum mechanics and general relativity.
Aims to describe gravity at the quantum level.
String theory and loop quantum gravity are examples.
A theoretical framework for a quantum theory of gravity.
Suggests that spacetime is not continuous but is made of discrete 'loops'.
An alternative to string theory.
A proposed theory of everything that unifies the five consistent superstring theories.
Exists in 11 spacetime dimensions.
A generalization of string theory.
A physical object that can have any number of spatial dimensions.
A key concept in string theory and M-theory.
A membrane-like object.
A quantum physics protocol where entanglement is created between two particles that have never interacted.
A key component of quantum teleportation.
Involves a measurement on two other particles.
A single theoretical force that combines two or more of the fundamental forces.
Electromagnetism and the weak force are combined into the electroweak force.
The goal of a grand unified theory.
The unified force of electromagnetism and the weak nuclear force.
First described by Sheldon Glashow, Abdus Salam, and Steven Weinberg.
Mediated by the W and Z bosons and the photon.
A model that unifies the electromagnetic, weak, and strong nuclear forces.
Often abbreviated as GUT.
Does not include gravity.
The study of the fundamental particles and forces of nature.
Uses particle accelerators to smash particles together.
The Standard Model is a key part of this field.
Another name for particle physics.
Studies particles at very high energies.
The Large Hadron Collider is a main tool.
The branch of physics that deals with temperature, heat, and energy.
Includes thermodynamics, statistical mechanics, and cryogenics.
Explains why hot things get cold.
The study of rigid matter, or solids.
Includes the study of crystal structure, electrical conductivity, and thermal properties.
The basis for semiconductors and other electronics.
The theory of how matter and energy behave at the atomic and subatomic level.
Includes concepts like superposition and entanglement.
Developed by physicists like Planck, Bohr, and Schrödinger.
The study of the motion of macroscopic objects.
Based on Isaac Newton's laws of motion.
Does not apply to objects moving near the speed of light or at the quantum scale.
The study of objects moving at speeds close to the speed of light.
Based on Einstein's theory of special relativity.
Accounts for time dilation and length contraction.
A set of equations in special relativity.
Relates the coordinates of an event in two different inertial frames of reference.
The basis for time dilation and length contraction.
The principle that the laws of mechanics are the same in all inertial frames of reference.
A cornerstone of classical mechanics.
Replaced by Lorentz invariance in special relativity.
The principle that the effects of gravity and acceleration are indistinguishable.
A key idea in Einstein's theory of general relativity.
Means an observer in a sealed box cannot tell if they are in gravity or accelerating.
A state in which all forces are balanced.
An object at rest is in this state.
The net force on the object is zero.
The average density of the universe needed to stop its expansion.
A key parameter in cosmology.
If the universe's density is greater, it will eventually collapse in a 'Big Crunch'.
A hypothetical ultimate fate of the universe.
All matter and energy are spread out evenly, and no more work can be done.
A state of maximum entropy.
A state where two or more objects in contact have the same temperature.
No net heat flows between them.
The basis of the zeroth law of thermodynamics.
A measure of a material's ability to conduct heat.
Metals have a high value, while air and foam have a low one.
Crucial for insulation.
The movement of a fluid caused by differences in temperature.
Warm air rises and cold air sinks.
Creates weather patterns.
The sudden flow of electricity between two charged objects.
Causes a small shock when you touch a doorknob after walking on carpet.
Often abbreviated as ESD.
A hypothetical particle that is a single north or south pole.
Has never been observed.
Predicted by some theories, but not by Maxwell's equations.
A type of physical theory that describes fundamental forces.
The Standard Model of particle physics is a type of this.
Relies on a mathematical concept called a gauge symmetry.
A property of a wave function.
Describes how the wave function changes when spatial coordinates are inverted.
Can be even or odd.
Semiconductor nanocrystals with quantum properties.
Emit light of a specific color based on their size.
Used in some high-end televisions for better color.
The wavelength of a particle.
Relates momentum to wavelength.
A key concept in wave-particle duality.
A series of radioactive decays that an unstable nucleus undergoes.
Ends when a stable nucleus is formed.
Uranium-238 decays into Lead-206 through one of these.
The process that powers stars.
Combines light atomic nuclei to form heavier ones.
Releases a tremendous amount of energy.
A hypothetical climatic effect resulting from a nuclear war.
Would be caused by smoke and dust blocking sunlight.
Would lead to a long-term cooling of the Earth.
The study of the fundamental constituents of matter and their interactions.
The Large Hadron Collider is a major tool in this field.
The Standard Model is the main theory.
A theoretical framework that combines quantum mechanics and special relativity.
Describes particles as excitations of underlying fields.
The Standard Model is an example of this.
The temporary appearance of elementary particles out of empty space.
A consequence of the Heisenberg uncertainty principle.
Leads to the Casimir effect.
A phenomenon where a particle passes through a potential energy barrier.
Not possible in classical physics.
Essential for nuclear fusion in the sun.
A material that conducts electricity with zero resistance.
Requires very low temperatures to operate.
Used in MRI machines.
A scientific instrument that uses light interference to make precise measurements.
The LIGO detectors are examples of this.
Can detect gravitational waves.
Approaches infinity at the center.
At the singularity, it is infinitely dense.
A key characteristic of a singularity.
A now-discredited theory of the universe.
Proposed that the universe has always existed and is unchanging.
Contradicted by the discovery of the cosmic microwave background.
The observation that the distance between galaxies is increasing.
First proposed by Edwin Hubble.
A key piece of evidence for the Big Bang theory.
A theory of the very early universe.
Proposes an extremely rapid expansion of space.
Solves several problems with the Big Bang theory.
A hypothetical form of energy that permeates all of space.
Thought to be responsible for the accelerating expansion of the universe.
Makes up most of the universe's mass-energy content.
A massive object that bends light from a more distant object.
Can create multiple images of the same distant galaxy.
A consequence of general relativity.
A theory of gravity developed by Albert Einstein.
Describes gravity as a curvature of spacetime.
Predicts black holes and gravitational waves.
A theory of spacetime developed by Albert Einstein.
Deals with objects moving at constant velocity.
Includes the famous equation E=mc².
The concept that every particle or quantum entity may be described as either a particle or a wave.
Light and electrons exhibit this property.
A cornerstone of quantum mechanics.
